sections.heading: ANOTHER
structure: another + number + plural noun (when a number comes in the middle)
examples: We need another chair.
Would you like another cappuccino?
If the cable doesn't fit, buy another cable (a different one).
I still need to take another three exams.
You can keep those tissues; I have another two packs.
I can't have another (= another child).
Do you want another? (= another drink)
sections.explanation: 'Another' means one more or a different one. Used with singular nouns, or plural nouns when a number is included.

sections.heading: OTHER
structure: determiner + other + singular noun (the second of two)
determiner + other + plural/uncountable noun (the remaining ones)
examples: We need other flavors.
Other information is on the website.
Look on other websites.
My right eye is itchy. The other eye is fine.
This cup is black coffee; the other cup has sugar.
I can fly on the 7th. My other option is the 8th.
These chips are for cookies; the other chips are for brownies.
My other stuff arrives next week.
sections.explanation: 'Other' refers to more of something, different ones, the second of two, or the remaining part of a group.

sections.heading: OTHERS (pronoun)
examples: Cara and Rachel are here. Where are the others? (the other children)
These two muffins don't contain nuts, but the others do.
I seem outgoing to my friends, but to others I look shy. (other people)
sections.explanation: 'Others' replaces a plural noun. 'The others' = the remaining people/things in a specific group.

sections.heading: NOT NEEDED: 'AN OTHER'
structure: Not used in modern English grammar
examples: ❌ an other book
❌ an other idea
✅ another book
✅ another idea
sections.explanation: You never need 'an other' as a grammar form.
